13.69.text:
Join me as the history of these hills comes
to life next on Missouri Outdoors.

39.72.text:
Hi and welcome to Missouri Outdoors, I’m
Kipp Woods.

42.32.text:
Today we’re in the Ozarks of southern Missouri
one of the most scenic regions of the state.

45.60.text:
Much of this area’s livelihood is tied to
the land and for many these trees.

49.75.text: It’s been that way for more than a century.

52.83.text:
On today’s show, we’re going to take a
look at some of the people that worked the

56.72.text:
timber
Including an era when Missouri was in the

60.44.text:
midst of a logging boom one that would have
a lasting impact on the lives and the landscape

67.74.text:
Though the rivers flow quietly through wooded
hills today, they were the sites of great

74.23.text:
These rivers once served as highways in moving
lumber from one point to another.

79.36.text:
We’ll see how some are working to recapture
the memories of those bygone days.

87.54.text:
During the past century, Missouri’s forests
have changed dramatically.

92.01.text:
The early decades of the 1900s saw many of
these hills stripped of their timber.

98.24.text:
The lumber was used for a growing country
but there was little regard for the natural

105.67.text:
Trees not cut were many times burned part
of a local tradition thought to promote the

110.43.text: growth of grasses and destroy ticks and snakes.

113.75.text:
The land was also choked by livestock grazing,
drought and erosion.

119.89.text: And as the forests dwindled, so did the wildlife.

122.29.text:
It would take a lot of education, fire suppression,
replanting of trees and proper management

129.05.text: to bring the forests and the resources back.

133.51.text:
Efforts by the Missouri Department of Conservation
would lead the way.

138.70.text: Help would also come from private individuals.

141.62.text:
One in particular has spent more than 50 years
building the foundation for strong and healthy

146.81.text:
forests not only during his lifetime, but
for future generations as well.

148.61.text:
It’s a pioneering practice started by one
that today benefits all.

156.54.text:
Narrator: In this small office in downtown
St. Louis, a man dreamed of a forest.

171.82.text: Slowly, quietly, patiently, the forest grew.

193.54.text: And this was not a small dream.

195.96.text: Answering machine: I’m out planting a forest.

197.87.text:
Please leave your name and number, and I’ll
try to get back to you before it matures.

210.77.text:
Narrator: Pioneer forest is the largest private
landholding in the state of Missouri, over

216.56.text:
150,000 acres, stretching across five counties
along the Current and Jacks Fork Rivers.

226.95.text:
Preserving and protecting the environment
through a vast section of Missouri’s Ozarks.

232.12.text: It’s the fulfillment of one man’s dream.

237.10.text: That dreamers name is Leo Drey.

240.52.text:
Clint Trammel: Leo is going to be one of those
people, who, at some time in the future, if

247.20.text:
not already, people are going to realize the
stature of what he has accomplished and what

253.05.text: he has done for this state.

255.76.text:
Narrator: Clint Trammel is forest manager
of Pioneer.

259.32.text:
He’s spent a career working on the forest,
and working with Leo Drey.

264.19.text:
Clint: I’ve been here almost thirty six
years now, and every morning I still look

271.53.text: forward to getting up and going to work.

272.83.text:
I could not have found a better place to spend
a career than to spend it right here on Pioneer

281.44.text:
Timber Surveyor: Ok Jerry we can take this
tree out.

286.52.text:
Narrator: What they do on Pioneer forest is
sustainable forest management.

290.95.text: Timber Surveyor: It’s got a DBH of 25.

292.36.text:
Narrator: A small group of six employees individually
selects trees for harvest, allowing the forest

299.54.text: as a whole to remain intact.

302.52.text:
This single tree management approach was an
essential part of Leo Drey’s vision.

306.94.text:
Timber Surveyor: Twenty six feet
Clint: One of the first things that Leo told

310.35.text:
us back then when we went to work was that
he wanted Pioneer to be a for-profit business,

316.35.text:
but he didn’t want to destroy the forest
in the process.

319.54.text:
After we harvest a tract of timber, any logger
that works on us would be willing to go back

324.86.text:
the next day and cut that tract again because
we have that quality and that much timber

329.43.text:
that is left after we get through and call
a sale closed.

334.22.text:
And all of the values and benefits that were
in that forest before we started logging are

340.92.text:
Clint: This one looks like its ninety seven
years old, based on the growth ring count.

345.30.text:
It was really beginning to slow down these
last few years, even though it was a dominant

350.54.text:
tree, apparently this tree was getting to
the point where it was about to start declining.

357.51.text: So it was time for this one to come down.

364.28.text:
Narrator: On another section of Pioneer Forest,
Chief Forester Terry Cunningham and L-A-D

374.09.text:
Foundation staff member Gregg Iffring discuss
the long term benefits of single tree selection.

379.29.text:
Terry Cunningham: You know the remarkable
thing about the uneven age management is we

382.80.text:
still have a forest here, maintain our woodland
character even though we’ve been harvesting

389.35.text: in here within the past two and a half years.

391.54.text:
That technique we’ve used three times on
this particular piece of ground, and what

397.74.text:
happens is we begin to develop structure in
here.

401.98.text:
Through our cut and selection we begin to
create these openings in the canopy and that’s

407.61.text:
what generates the fuel for these seedlings
to grow up into that sapling class.

412.86.text:
Terry Cunningham: I worked for Mr. Drey since
1972, thirty three years.

416.84.text:
I have the utmost respect for him and what
he has done and accomplished in the Ozarks.

425.86.text:
Pioneer Forest is a business, and it contributes
to the local economies, all our trees are

431.87.text:
sold to local loggers and local sawmills,
it has quite an impact.

435.83.text: We harvest several million feet a year.

438.51.text:
We’ve cut many of these tracts three different
times and we still have a woodland on the

444.27.text:
Narrator: Ronnie Harper, a longtime timber
contractor with Pioneer, has come to understand

452.01.text: the importance of a sustainable forest.

454.93.text:
Ronnie Harper: Ninety percent of the logs
I cut in the sawmill come from Pioneer Forest.

461.50.text:
Probably twenty five families in my bunch
eat because of Pioneer Forest.

467.88.text:
When I first started, it was hard for me to
walk around some of the better trees that

473.29.text:
we’ve left, you know, that, when we go back
through it twenty years later, we got some

478.21.text:
nice big trees that we can cut then so, it’s
more of an even type stand.

482.59.text:
I’ve been there long enough, it’s kind
of neat, I’m going back over the same stuff

487.15.text:
that I’ve done twenty years ago, it kind
of shows you what timber does when it’s

494.04.text:
Greg Iffring: I mean I’m sold on what Leo
took on and stuck with.

500.00.text:
The idea of being able to go into a forest
and do single tree selection management, and

504.55.text:
leave behind more trees that are cut, and
leave behind the best trees and cut the worst.

512.52.text:
The fact that he went into the Ozarks and
used this method to restore forests on a landscape

520.70.text: scale, have got to be among his greatest contributions.

524.22.text:
Narrator: Drey’s contributions to Missouri’s
environment are legendary.

530.62.text:
As he acquired land throughout the Ozarks,
certain areas were deemed so significant they

536.31.text:
had to be made available to the public; Dillard
Mill State Historic Site, Clifty Creek Conservation

551.16.text:
And many other significant natural areas were
purchased by Drey and donated to the state

558.76.text:
When the spectacular Greer Spring was threatened
with development, Leo stepped in.

565.33.text:
Clint: Greer Springs is such a unique place,
once Leo saw this move to make it a commercial

571.56.text:
development he immediately took action to
see that, if he couldn’t head that off.

580.00.text:
At some point during the discussions, Leo
and the Busch Corporation put in enough money

587.68.text:
to bring the price of it down so the U.S.
Forest Service could acquire it.

594.81.text:
And the natural beauty of that will be preserved
forever.

598.89.text:
Narrator: Leo Drey also started the Open Space
Council in St. Louis, and helped to form Missouri’s

608.24.text:
He provided leadership and support for environmental
groups throughout the region.

613.08.text:
In 2003 Leo and his wife Kay completed their
greatest achievement; the donation of the

624.04.text:
entire 154,000 acre Pioneer Forest, to a private
charitable foundation.

629.94.text:
The purpose was to insure that vast tract
of Ozark land, critically important to the

638.04.text:
watersheds of the Current and Jack’s Fork
River systems would be managed sustainably,

644.27.text: and be open to the public forever.

648.94.text:
It was a staggering achievement; the largest
conservation related charitable contribution

655.82.text:
Greg Iffring: The news of that donation went
out and it was slow to percolate around Missouri

662.84.text:
But there has been now wide coverage in the
media and the most recent and perhaps the

668.27.text:
most important was the Time Magazine issue
where Leo and Kay were noted among the top

676.20.text:
ten philanthropic gifts of for the previous
year.

680.12.text:
The value we calculated of the donation of
Pioneer and its assets is about 180 million

685.98.text:
dollars, so a huge gift, and a wonderful gift
for Missouri.

693.15.text:
Narrator: Many of Leo Drey’s battles are
behind him now.

700.16.text:
Over ninety years old, Leo and his wife Kay
continue to live in their modest St. Louis

708.26.text:
But when reminiscing about the Ozarks and
Pioneer Forest, Leo still has a twinkle in

715.27.text:
It’s the look of a man whose dreams have
come true.

719.24.text:
Leo Drey: Well I get to much credit for doing
just what I wanted to do.

724.17.text:
All I was doing was what came natural, I was
trying to put together this demonstration

732.02.text:
area that would show that you could manage
through individual tree selection and not

742.35.text:
So while I was putting Pioneer Forest together,
I was running around in the backwoods country

749.12.text:
and meeting people and enjoying those people,
they had their feet on the ground and I enjoyed

756.97.text:
I enjoyed hiking in the forest, and I certainly
enjoyed canoeing the clear Ozark streams which

767.89.text:
were running clear and full because of the
way the Conservation Department was beginning

773.26.text: to get the woods fires under control.

779.62.text:
And uh, as I say I get credit for doing what
I wanted to do which I enjoyed doing.

787.23.text:
Narrator: Integral to Leo’s accomplishments
has been his fifty year marriage to his wife

794.23.text:
An environmental activist of note in her own
right, Kay continues her work protecting Missouri’s

801.71.text:
Kay Drey: When I met Leo, I met him at a wedding,
and I said “oh, do you have a tree, I’m

809.29.text:
And Leo looked at me really strangely and
walked away and that was our first meeting.

813.94.text:
You know I did love the out of doors, I had
had virtually no camping experience as a child

820.68.text:
but I really loved trees and clouds and just
open space

827.64.text:
And I guess politically we agreed on things
too.

831.11.text:
Leo was always a political animal when I first
knew him, still is.

835.79.text:
Narrator: History remembers great men by the
deeds they’ve accomplished.

841.58.text: In Leo Drey’s case it’s a staggering legacy.

846.49.text:
Huge tracts of land preserved, new management
techniques developed, environmental groups

853.64.text:
created and nurtured, charitable giving on
a monumental scale.

863.96.text:
His dreams are larger than any of us could
imagine, and he’s had the drive, persistence

871.19.text: and creativity to make those dreams come true.

875.70.text:
But there is another more subtle measure of
great men.

879.63.text:
It can be found in the hearts of the people
around them.

886.09.text:
Clint: You know, if I hadn’t taken this
job with Pioneer, I would never have known

895.75.text:
But having worked with Leo and knowing the
quality of the man that he is, I value every

903.20.text: day that I’ve worked for him.

907.02.text:
His values, his long tern vision, his dedication
to the natural resources of Missouri has made

917.83.text:
this one of the most enjoyable experiences
I think I could have ever had.

930.77.text:
Kipp: Although these hills are relatively
quiet today they were the sight of great activity

937.73.text:
Century-old stories about the great logging
boom in Missouri have been passed down from

944.09.text:
But for some, reminders of the past are found
not only in the trees, but also in nearby

952.39.text:
Narrator: Nestled among the Ozark hills of
southern Missouri are the cool, clear, spring-fed

961.62.text:
Today, it’s one of the top destinations
for recreational floaters who use canoes,

967.27.text:
kayaks and rubber rafts to make their way
down stream.

971.27.text:
But years ago, this river and others in the
area were known for a different type of float;

977.76.text:
one that traces its roots back to Missouri’s
tall timber.

984.90.text:
In the late 18 and early 19-hundreds, the
region was the site of great activity.

990.55.text:
Railroad ties and lumber produced from the
Ozark forests helped develop the nation.

995.45.text:
Lumber for growing cities and ties for the
railroads stretching across the plains.

1002.14.text:
It was a time when the Ozark forests meant
jobs; back breaking manual labor for men with

1009.64.text:
Robert: Between livestock and timber, that’s
about all there was.

1014.76.text:
Narrator: Trees were cut and many times, railroad
ties were created on-site.

1021.38.text:
Tie Hackers, as they were called, earned ten
cents for each tie produced.

1025.66.text: They could hew a tie in about one hour.

1028.75.text:
But getting the wood to their destination
was no easy chore.

1032.59.text:
Ray Joe: You have to remember that there were
no roads, other than wagon trails, back then.

1039.15.text: So the river was the main way for transportation.

1044.45.text:
Narrator: Many ties and logs were moved by
a river drive to the nearest railroad crossing

1050.63.text:
Some of the larger river drives contained
more than two hundred and fifty thousand free-floating

1055.61.text: ties and took months to complete.

1059.29.text:
Another method was to attach ties together
to form a long raft.

1062.84.text:
Ray Joe: They free-floated logs and ties both,
but the main thing down here on ties was they

1072.79.text: would nail them together with lash poles.

1075.43.text:
That’s saplings about three or four inches
through, twenty feet long.

1081.07.text:
And raft as many as 12-hundred ties down the
river.

1085.82.text:
Narrator: The men working these drives were
called ‘river hogs’.

1089.17.text:
They were wet for weeks on end for a dollar
seventy five a day.

1093.93.text: It was not a job to be envied.

1097.11.text:
When the drive reached the railroad crossing,
men, teams of horses and mules, and wagons

1103.25.text:
would be standing by to pull the ties from
the river and carry them to waiting railroad

1109.45.text:
While the Current River is no longer an avenue
of commerce, remnants of the past remain.

1114.34.text:
Ray Joe: This is one of the many logs that
was left here from the timber days of the

1119.48.text:
1880s and early 1900s; washed in here got
loose from the loggers that was making the

1125.46.text:
log drive and come to rest here on the gravel
bar.

1130.62.text:
There are hundreds of these things that are
still in the river along with many, many ties

1137.09.text: that got loose from the rafters.

1141.27.text:
Narrator: Ray Joe Hastings is trying to keep
memories of the past alive.

1148.35.text:
Along with Gene Braschler and several others
in the Doniphan area, they’ve spearheaded

1153.34.text: efforts to bring a bygone era back to life.

1158.98.text:
Robert: I think we’re trying to put a tie
raft together.

1187.73.text:
Ray Joe: the last tie raft supposedly came
down in 1931 and I always wanted to try it.

1194.94.text:
Price: Ties were, you might say, the life-blood
of this area.

1198.23.text: Ray Joe: We brought a tie raft down in 2000.

1202.20.text:
250 ties is what we’re bringing down this
time.

1205.70.text:
We’ve got a lot of equipment to move our
stuff forklifts to lift ties.

1211.07.text:
But they had to do it shouldering them and
carry to the river and toss them in so no

1220.63.text: We’re just kind of fooling around.

1223.42.text: They had to really work at it.

1224.56.text:
Gene: Of course when we start down the river,
don’t be surprised if we have a mishap.

1231.70.text:
It’s happened before, you know, and it could
happen again.

1234.35.text:
Crew: It looks to me like it’s going to
be a lot of work.

1249.74.text:
(Cheering)
Narrator: 16-foot push poles help the crew

1253.66.text:
to guide the raft around snags, shallow areas
and bends in the river.

1259.18.text:
Long “sweeps” at the front and rear of
the raft are also used.

1263.75.text:
Ray Joe: If you count the blades that hang
over each end, it’s going to be around 200

1273.12.text:
It’s not hard on the long, still holes where
there are no snags or shoals.

1280.51.text:
But, yeah, there’s places where it’s very
hard to get through.

1285.55.text: You’ve got to really be on your toes.

1288.35.text: Nat: Watch the center there Gene.

1296.95.text:
Crew: There’s just a narrow spot we can
go through.

1302.89.text:
Gene: Ray Joe, I think we need to hug the
extreme left bank.

1305.61.text: Crew: Is that where you want to be?

1311.77.text: I told you it was going to be exciting (laugh).

1342.44.text:
Narrator: Much like the drives of the past,
the river would once again claim a few ties

1351.02.text:
But as the 7-mile journey neared its end,
onlookers reveled at the site of the raft

1357.44.text:
An unusual event that was not so uncommon
a century ago.

1364.61.text:
Woman: I really admire these people who are
doing this.

1370.25.text: It’s something you don’t see every day.

1374.52.text:
Gene: I think it’s worth every bit of the
effort to try to put pride back in the people

1382.06.text: and some knowledge in the timber industry.

1385.36.text:
And I think these trips down the river on
the raft will help to do that.

1419.62.text:
Martha Daniels: If you’re looking for a
sweet and nutty dessert or just a special

1446.97.text: snack treat, we’ve got the recipe for you.

1450.01.text:
Our blackberry-pecan squares have a buttery
toffee flavor, enhanced by toasted pecans.

1455.82.text:
And it’s all complimented by the wonderful
taste of blackberries.

1460.08.text:
First, grease an 8 inch square baking pan
with butter and set aside.

1464.76.text: Stir together flour, soda and salt.

1467.92.text:
Cream butter and sugar with a mixer about
3 minutes until fluffy.

1475.04.text: Add eggs and vanilla and beat.

1478.55.text:
Continue to beat slowly, adding in the flour
mixture until combined.

1485.88.text: Gradually add 3/4 cup toasted pecans and mix.

1490.49.text: Then spread the batter in a pan.

1493.62.text:
Sprinkle berries on top, and scatter on remaining
nuts.

1498.76.text: Bake at 325 degrees for 50 to 55 minutes.

1506.68.text:
Let it cool for 30 minutes and sprinkle with
powdered sugar.

1513.75.text:
Getting out on a summer morning to pick blackberries
is a refreshing experience, especially when

1518.41.text:
you know everyone will relish the sweet berry
flavors in blackberry pecan squares.

1524.75.text:
If you’d like the recipe, check our website
or just write to us.

1527.52.text:
We’ll have the address for you at the end
of the show.

1532.57.text:
Josh Bullock: When you can’t find enough
time or opportunity to hit the woods or take

1541.85.text:
to the trail, you can still explore Missouri’s
outdoors.

1544.61.text: All you have to do is go surfing!

1547.12.text:
If you love to hike, we’ve got the trail
for you!

1549.10.text:
You can find a nice hike close to home by
searching trails by county.

1553.93.text:
Or find a special spot by selecting the class
of trail you prefer, like a primitive or disable-accessible

1561.10.text:
Or choose the type of trail you want: something
that offers an interpretive hike or one that

1565.89.text:
allows horses or bicycles, in addition to
hikers.

1569.04.text:
And you can even access information on the
adopt-a-trail program.

1573.04.text:
To make surfing Missouri easy, our web site
is designed to work with any web browser.

1577.57.text:
Use our web address or type “Missouri conservation”
into any search engine.

1585.37.text:
Thanks for watching, and don't forget, if
you get the chance, why not head out and enjoy

1594.50.text:
Narrator: To receive a copy of today’s recipe,
send us your name and address and the specific

1599.73.text:
name of the recipe or check it out on our
website.
